body: Crowds coiled around department stores, sidewalk Santas rang bells, Christmas lights glittered on the tree at Rockefeller Center. But behind the holiday cheer yesterday lay the specter of a transit strike, a city without the subways and buses that carry seven million people a day in and out like tides. To many New Yorkers, like Bernice Coffie, 28,
title: Long, Cold Hikes Envisioned If City Transit Workers Walk

body: To the Editor: ''Diner of Song and Story'' (F.Y.I., Nov. 17), about my song ''Tom's Diner'' and the Tom's Restaurants in Morningside Heights and Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, was great. It clears up something I explain all the time, although I hear the Brooklyn one is great too. SUZANNE VEGA Upper West Side
title: Crime On the Mind; The A and B Sides Of Tom's Restaurant

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; Four Brothers, Four Working-Class Heroes

body: To the Editor: I am one of those parents who also hated playgrounds (thankfully, my kids have aged out). title: Not So Jaded By Playground Duty

title: Free Tutoring Fails to Draw Many Students

body: It is the undisputed king of the Brooklyn skyline, the most populous borough's only widely recognized piece of architecture that is not a roller coaster. title: MY BROOKLYN; A Tower of Dentists Wears a Golden Crown

body: Salvator Altchek, known for 67 years as the $5 doctor to the melting pot of Brooklyn, especially the poorer residents of affluent Brooklyn Heights, died on Tuesday. He was 92. He continued to work until two months ago, but gave up house calls five years ago. He delivered thousands of babies and generally attended to the health needs of anyone who
title: Salvator Altchek, 'the $5 Doctor' of Brooklyn, Dies at 92

body: The percentage of students who dropped out of New York City high schools rose last year for the third year in a row, the Board of Education said yesterday. title: Dropout Rate Rises, but Wait: 4-Year Graduations Do, Too

body: THE Brooklyn dining scene has changed drastically in a decade. title: RESTAURANTS; A Fresh Start For a Pioneer Of Park Slope

body: To the Editor: Re ''The Bunker, an Orphan, Finds a Temporary Home'' (March 3): I am glad that the fine Purchase Building beneath the Brooklyn Bridge will be used for a temporary emergency command center, and quite possibly saved from truncation or demolition. title: Is City Inviting Terrorism At the Brooklyn Bridge?
